awd_titl_txt: Growing Computer Science Literacy via Informal Learning Communities among Incarcerated and Formerly Incarcerated Men and Women
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches, and resources for use in a variety of settings. This Pilots and Feasibility Studies project will design and study computer science education programs in three New York State prisons and cutting-edge computer science learning spaces in New York City and Bennington, VT for recently released men and women. These two sites of investment will be designed and operated with the goals of bridging informal STEM education inside the prison and post-release. The project aims to help incarcerated and formerly incarcerated men and women gain hands-on experience and technical fluency in computer science. The project will also help people build effective pathways that link training and informal learning communities in prison to professional and educational success after prison.

The research will examine how informal STEM learning can 1) provide incarcerated and post-incarceration populations more effective pathways into computer science and technology professions, and 2) help revitalize neighborhoods struggling with high rates of incarceration and high rates of adults under correctional supervision. Results will be shared among the STEM learning community and prison educators through existing networks, scholarly and journalistic publications, and conferences. As a pilot program, this project aims to develop a comprehensive, rigorous, and transferable model that may be used as a resource in other prison education programs as well as in rural and urban communities across the United States seeking to address economic and educational inequalities of post-incarceration life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project helped bring computer literacy to incarcerated and formerly incarcerated men and women in New York State. Support from NSF allowed Bard College and Bennington College to build new DOCCS compliant computer science labs in two upstate prisons, to bring new computer science coursework to prisons, to encourage self-directed learning in computer science among incareracted individuals, and to foster informal communities of learning about computer science and its applications both inside the prison and after release. We also opened a computer science laboratory in Bennington, VT to help train formerly incacerated individuals. This lab became a popular resource for a handful of individuals, and as we built up our relations with social workers, parole officers, and others we were on the cusp of welcoming a large cohort of new participants when COVID-19 struck. 

While this project faced many headwinds -- including COVID-19 barring all access the facilities we work in -- we are happy to report that over 50 incarcerated students benefited from the resources of this project, that informal learning communites around computer science are ongoing, and that training in computer science proved instrumental in securing employment post-release for a number of our students. The indidividuals that participated in our programs did so with growing enthusiasm for the work. 

This project also crafted a novel approach to informal learning communities in computer science, and we continue to share the promising results on our educational innovations with other prison educators. We are also working on publications for education journals to share our findings with a broader audience. 


Last Modified: 08/18/2022
Modified by: David Bond
